title: How to Charge Your PSP with the Original Charger or USB

steps.title: Locate the AC adapter port.
steps.content: Locate the AC adapter port. The AC adapter connects to the yellow outlet on the bottom right of your device. Your PSP comes with a cable that fits snugly into this outlet. Don't have the original cable? Shop AC adapters on Amazon.

steps.title: Connect your AC Adapter to the PSP and the wall.
steps.content: Connect your AC Adapter to the PSP and the wall. With the AC adapter connected to your PSP, plug the other end into a power outlet. [1] X Research source The PSP uses a 5V AC Adapter. If you plan to replace the adapter make sure that the voltage matches to avoid damaging your system.

steps.title: Wait for the power light to turn orange.
steps.content: Wait for the power light to turn orange. The power light will display a blinking green light at first, then turn solid orange, indicating a proper connection. If the light never turns orange, double-check that the AC adapter is plugged in correctly and that the battery pack at the back of the PSP is installed properly. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Charge for 4-5 hours.
steps.content: Charge for 4-5 hours. This will fully charge your PSP, allowing for longer sessions of use.

steps.title: Turn on your PSP.
steps.content: Turn on your PSP. If you have some remaining battery power and wish to charge your PSP using a USB cord rather than an AC Adapter, you can do this by adjusting the settings on your PSP. You can’t charge a PSP with a USB unless the device is able to turn on. [3] X Research source Even if the proper setting is already turned on, the PSP must be powered on to use USB charging. Note: This method is not supported by the first-generation PSP models (series 1000). Games cannot be played while using USB charging.

steps.title: From the opening menu, go to "Settings."
steps.content: From the opening menu, go to "Settings." Settings can be accessed by scrolling left from the opening menu. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Select "System Settings."
steps.content: Select "System Settings." Scroll down in the “Settings” menu to access the system settings. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Turn on "USB Charge."
steps.content: Turn on "USB Charge." This option appears in the System Settings menu and will activate the ability to charge by USB. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Turn on "USB Auto Connect."
steps.content: Turn on "USB Auto Connect." This option is located in the same menu just below “USB Charge.” [7] X Research source

steps.title: Connect your mini USB cable to the PSP.
steps.content: Connect your mini USB cable to the PSP. The mini USB outlet is located on the top of your device. [8] X Research source The PSP uses a 5 pin Mini-B USB port. Any USB cable that fits this spec will work.

steps.title: Connect the other end of the USB cable to a power source.
steps.content: Connect the other end of the USB cable to a power source. You can connect this end of the cable to a computer or an electrical outlet with a USB wall adapter . [9] X Research source If you are connecting your mini USB cord to your computer instead of an electrical outlet, then both the laptop and the PSP need to be powered on in order for the charge to take place.

steps.title: Wait for the power light to turn orange.
steps.content: Wait for the power light to turn orange. The power light will display a blinking green light at first, then turn solid orange, indicating a proper connection. If the light never turns orange, double-check that the AC adapter is plugged in correctly and that the battery pack at the back of the PSP is installed properly. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Charge for 6-8 hours.
steps.content: Charge for 6-8 hours. USB charging is slower than using an AC adapter. A longer wait will fully charge your PSP, allowing for longer sessions of use.

steps.title: Get your hands on a PSP Go charging dock or PSP N100 charger.
steps.content: Get your hands on a PSP Go charging dock or PSP N100 charger . The PSP Go takes a different charging method than other PSP models. To charge your PSP Go, either get your hands on the PSP Go charging dock or the PSP N100 charger. The PSP N100 is more affordable than the charging dock, but both are available to purchase online.

steps.title: Insert the charger into the port on the bottom of the device.
steps.content: Insert the charger into the port on the bottom of the device. Once you’ve got your hands on the proper charger, insert it into the charging port on the bottom of your device. An orange light should start shining, indicating that your device is charging. Let it fully charge for at least 4 hours before using the device. [11] X Research source
